title: Emergency sandwich patch repair via right ventricular\nincision for postinfarction ventricular septal defects: a case series
patient:
A 69-year-old male patient who suffered from chest pain for five consecutive days was
emergency taken to our hospital due to worsening of the chest pain. The patient’s
diagnosis was an inferior STEMI, and emergency PCI was performed for the right coronary
artery. IABP was subsequently initiated due to the ongoing preshock status. A VSD was
detected by TTE, and emergency VSD repair was performed. We used a large oval bovine
pericardial patch for the first patch because the ruptured septum extended along the long
axis (). The postoperative course was uneventful without
development of a residual shunt at follow-up after 6 months.
